supporting.text: Cats are obligate carnivores, and their primary hydration source in the wild is water from prey, making water the most natural and necessary drink for them.

attacks.text: Cats are obligate carnivores, and their primary hydration source in the wild is water from prey, making water the most natural and necessary drink for them.
Some cats may require electrolyte solutions or specialized veterinary-recommended fluids in cases of dehydration or illness, not just water.
While specialized fluids are needed in medical cases, these are exceptions and do not negate the general rule that water is the primary and healthiest hydration source for cats.
Milk is often given to cats as a treat or supplement, and while not a primary hydration source, it is an alternative liquid they consume.
Most adult cats are lactose intolerant, and milk can cause digestive issues, making it unsuitable as a regular hydration source.

supporting.text: Milk can cause digestive issues like diarrhea in many adult cats due to lactose intolerance, reinforcing that water is the safest option.

attacks.text: Milk can cause digestive issues like diarrhea in many adult cats due to lactose intolerance, reinforcing that water is the safest option.
Some cats are lactose-tolerant and can digest milk without issues, making milk a viable alternative in certain cases.
Even lactose-tolerant cats may develop digestive issues if milk is given in large quantities or too frequently.
Special lactose-free milk products for cats exist, providing hydration without digestive risks.
Lactose-free milk products are often unnecessary and more expensive than water, which is universally safe.

supporting.text: Veterinary guidelines universally recommend fresh water as the sole beverage for cats to maintain kidney health and prevent dehydration.

attacks.text: Veterinary guidelines universally recommend fresh water as the sole beverage for cats to maintain kidney health and prevent dehydration.
Some cats may require electrolyte solutions or specialized veterinary-recommended fluids in cases of severe dehydration or illness.
Such electrolyte solutions are still fundamentally water-based and administered under strict veterinary supervision, not as general beverages.
Milk is occasionally tolerated by certain cats as a treat, though it is not a hydration substitute.
Lactose intolerance affects most adult cats, making milk consumption potentially harmful despite anecdotal tolerance.

supporting.text: Other liquids, such as juice or flavored drinks, often contain sugars or additives harmful to cats, further supporting water as the only appropriate drink.

attacks.text: Other liquids, such as juice or flavored drinks, often contain sugars or additives harmful to cats, further supporting water as the only appropriate drink.
Some specially formulated cat drinks, like lactose-free milk substitutes, are safe and beneficial for cats, providing hydration without harmful additives.
Even lactose-free substitutes may contain unnecessary calories or artificial ingredients that could lead to obesity or digestive issues over time.
In emergency situations, electrolyte solutions designed for pets can be necessary for rehydration and are not strictly water.
Electrolyte solutions should only be used under veterinary supervision and are not a replacement for regular water intake in healthy cats.

supporting.text: Cats have a low thirst drive, so providing clean water consistently is critical to avoid urinary tract diseases, which are common in dehydrated cats.

attacks.text: Cats have a low thirst drive, so providing clean water consistently is critical to avoid urinary tract diseases, which are common in dehydrated cats.
Some cats can obtain sufficient hydration from wet food alone, reducing their reliance on drinking water directly.
Wet food alone may not provide enough hydration for all cats, especially those with pre-existing health conditions or in hot climates.
Certain cat breeds, like the Maine Coon, naturally have a higher thirst drive and may not face the same dehydration risks.
Even breeds with higher thirst drives can develop urinary tract diseases if water quality or availability is poor.
